list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Which of the following statements is false?


- I.$\hspace{1em}$Electrons have greater mass than protons and neutronsII.$\hspace{1em}$Protons and neutrons are in the nucleusIII.$\hspace{1em}$Protons and electrons are charged subatomic particlesIV.$\hspace{1em}$Electrons are located outside the nucleus



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II and IV only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I only
list.markScheme:
D
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Electrons have negligible mass.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The nuclear symbol for an isotope of iodine is $\ce{^{125}_{53}I}$. Which of the following is correct about the isotope?

Atomic NumberMass NumberNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons$\hspace{1em}$ A.$\hspace{1em}$53125537253$\hspace{1em}$ B.$\hspace{1em}$53125725353$\hspace{1em}$ C.$\hspace{1em}$12553537272$\hspace{1em}$ D.$\hspace{1em}$12553535372
list.markScheme:
A
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/42307e35-8608-4db2-8772-65b60ebe1e65/images/67b4491b-77e7-4bdb-ab9a-3bfc9f01f1dd/2.1-48.png)


The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The atom of an element Q has an atomic number of 27 and a mass number of 60. Which of the following statements is true about the subatomic particles of the atom of element Q?


- I.$\hspace{1em}$Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 protonsII.$\hspace{1em}$Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 27 electronsIII.$\hspace{1em}$Atom of element Q has 27 electrons and 60 neutronsIV.$\hspace{1em}$Atom of element Q has 27 protons and 33 neutrons



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and IV only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$II and IV only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
list.markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number is the number of protons. The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. For a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which of the following is not a physical property of an isotope of an element with fewer neutrons in its atom?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Lower mass
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Faster rate of diffusion
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Higher density
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Lower melting and boiling points
list.markScheme:
C
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Isotopes with fewer neutrons will have a lower density

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Isoelectronic species are atoms or ions with the same number of electrons. Which of the following are isoelectronic species?


- I.$\ce{Al^3+}$II.$\ce{Mg^2+}$III.$\ce{O^2-}$



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The correct answer is that all three species are isoelectronic. Isoelectronic species have the same number of electrons despite being different elements or ions. Aluminum in its neutral state has 13 electrons, but when it loses three electrons to form $\ce{Al^{3+}},$ it has 10 remaining electrons. Magnesium has 12 electrons when neutral, and when it loses two to form $\ce{Mg^{2+}},$ it also has 10 electrons. Oxygen, on the other hand, has 8 electrons in its neutral state, but when it gains two to form $\ce{O^{2-}},$ it reaches a total of 10 electrons. Since all three ions have ten electrons, they are isoelectronic.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The isotopes of carbon $\ce{^{12}C}$ and $\ce{^{13}C}$:


- I.$\hspace{1em}$have the same atomic numberII.$\hspace{1em}$have the same physical propertiesIII.$\hspace{1em}$have the same chemical properties



- A.$\hspace{1em}$I and III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons that differ only in terms of their physical properties.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
How many electrons are there in $\ce{^{35}_{17}Cl^-}$?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 17
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 18
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 35
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 36
list.markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The atomic number is 17, hence there are 17 protons and 17 electrons in the atom (since atom is neutral). The ion with a charge of (1-) means that the atom has gained 1 electron and therefore, contains 18 electrons.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five species.
SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S8810T9108U101010V101210
Which two species are isotopes of the same element?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$R and S
- B.$\hspace{1em}$S and T
- C.$\hspace{1em}$T and U
- D.$\hspace{1em}$U and V
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
Species R and S have the same number of protons but also the same number of neutrons so cannot be isotopes. S is an anion of element R.
Species T is the only species in the table with 9 protons so cannot have an isotope with another species in the table because it is a different element.
This leaves species U and V which both have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons so they are isotopes.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
What happens to an atom if it loses two electrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$It becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of $2+.$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$It becomes a positively charged anion with a charge of $2+.$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$It becomes a negatively charged anion with a charge of $2-.$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$It becomes a negatively charged cation with a charge of $2-.$
list.markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
When an atom loses two electrons, it becomes a positively charged cation with a charge of $2+.$
Atoms are electrically neutral when they have equal numbers of protons and electrons. However, when electrons are removed, the balance shifts, leaving more positively charged protons than negatively charged electrons. The result is the formation of a cation, or positively charged ion. Since two electrons are lost, the charge on the resulting ion is $2+,$ indicating that the number of protons exceeds the number of electrons by two.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
An atom has the nuclear symbol $\ce{^{35}_{17}X}.$ Which statement is correct?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$It has 17 protons, 18 neutrons, and 18 electrons.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$It has 18 protons, 17 neutrons, and 17 electrons.
list.markScheme:
B
`
$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
When identifying a isotope, the chemical symbol is written also
$\ce{_Z^A X}$
where $Z$ is the atomic number, or number of protons and $A$ is the mass number, thes sum of the number of protons and neutrons.
In the isotope $\ce{^{35}_{17}X},$ the atomic number is 17.  There are 17 protons in the nucleus. The mass number is 35. This is the sum of protons and neutrons. To find the number of neutrons, subtract the atomic number from the mass number: $35 - 17 = 18$ neutrons. Since this is a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, meaning it also has 17 electrons.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Bromine has two stable isotopes: bromine$-$79 and bromine$-$81. What is the relative atomic mass of bromine (Br)?
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
IsotopeRelative AbundanceAtomic Mass$^{79}$Br50.69%78.92$^{81}$Br49.31%80.92


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 78.5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 80.1
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 81.2
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 79.9
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:  
Relative atomic mass of bromine can be calcualted answer
$A_r  = 0.5069\times78.92 + 0.4931\times80.92 = 79.9062$
$\underline{\textrm{Alternative Method}}$:
$^{79}$Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 79
$^{81}$Br atomic mass can be rounded up to 81
Since the relative abundance of both isotopes is about 50% each, the relative atomic mass of bromine should be close to 80.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Which statement about the mass spectrum of an element is correct?


- I.The tallest peak always represents the heaviest isotope.II.The relative abundance of an isotope is indicated by its peak height.III.The mass/charge ratio is displayed on the horizontal axis.



- A. $\hspace{1em}$I and II
- B. $\hspace{1em}$II and III
- C. $\hspace{1em}$I and III
- D. $\hspace{1em}$I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In a mass spectrum, the horizontal axis shows the mass$\text{--to--}$charge ratio $(m/z),$ and the height of each peak reflects the relative abundance of that isotope. This means the taller the peak, the more abundant the isotope is in the sample: the tallest peak is the most abundant isotope.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: The atom of element X has a mass number of 127 and has 74 neutrons. The ion derived from X has 54 electrons. - Calculate the number of protons of element X. [1] - State the nuclear symbol of the ion formed (refer to the periodic table). [2] - An isotope of X has a mass number of 132. Determine the number of neutrons in its atom. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Number of protons = 127 – 74 = 53 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Number of protons ($Z$) = mass number($A$) – number of neutrons($N$)
- Nuclear symbol: $_{53}^{127}\textrm{I}$ $^{-}$  $\checkmark$ $\checkmark$



- $\textit{Note: One mark for the charge and one mark for the nuclear symbol.}$



- $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$



- The atomic number of the element X is 53 (number of protons). Therefore, it corresponds to iodine with a mass number $A= 127$ (referring to the periodic table). The number of electrons in the ion formed is 54. This means that the atom has gained one electron, and the overall charge of the ion is $(1-).$


- Since it is an isotope, the number of protons is the same for all atoms of isotopes of the same element. $\checkmark$
  Number of $\textrm{neutrons} = 132 - 53 = \ $79 neutrons $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  number of neutrons = mass number $-$ number of protons

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The following table shows the number of subatomic particles present in five different species.
SpeciesNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsR888S11810T9108U101010V121012
Which species are ions?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$R and S
- B.$\hspace{1em}$S and T
- C.$\hspace{1em}$T and U
- D.$\hspace{1em}$U and V
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Ions of an element do not have the same numbers of protons and electrons.
Only species S and T do not have the same number of protons and electrons, so they are ions.
Note: S and T are not ions of the same element, but both have nonzero charge so are considered ions.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Which combination is correct for $\ce{^{41}_{19}K{^+}}?$
$\mbox{}\\[-15pts]$
$\hspace{1.em}$Number of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electronsA.192218B.192220C.224120D.221918
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The nuclear symbol notation allows to deduce the number of protons, neutrons and electrons.
$\LARGE{\ce{_Z^A X^q}}$X$\textrm{Chemical symbol}$$\hspace{0.1em}$$\mathbf{A}$Mass numberprotons + neutrons$\mathbf{Z}$Atomic numberprotons$\mathbf{q}$Chargeprotons $-$ electrons
In this symbol:


- $Z = 19$, the number of protons.
- $A=41$, there are $41 - 19 = 22$ neutrons.
- $q = +1$, there are $19-1=18$ electrons.

This question is categorized as easy as students must be able to calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons by interpreting the nuclear symbol notation.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
In a mass spectrum, the tallest peak is observed at $m/z = 40.$ Which of the following elements is most likely to produce this peak?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$Ar
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Br
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Ne
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Zr
list.markScheme:
A

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In mass spectrometry, the $m/z$ value represents the mass to charge ratio of an ion. Most ions formed in a mass spectrometer are singly charged (1+), so the $m/z$ value is equal to the mass number of the isotope. A peak at 40 suggests an ion with a mass of 40 and a charge of $+1.$ Argon has a common isotope, $\ce{^{40}Ar}$ in line with its relative atomic mass of 39.95.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Complete the following table:
Nuclear SymbolNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons$_{62}^{153}\textrm{Sm}$6281120$_{26}^{56}\textrm{Fe}^{2+}$26$_{46}^{103}\textrm{Pd}$46161618
$\ $
list.markScheme:
Nuclear SymbolNumber of protonsNumber of neutronsNumber of electrons$_{62}^{153}\textrm{Sm}$629162$\checkmark$$_{81}^{201}\textrm{Tl}$8112081$\checkmark$$_{26}^{56}\textrm{Fe}^{2+}$263024$\checkmark$$_{46}^{103}\textrm{Pd}$465746$\checkmark$$_{16}^{32}\textrm{S}^{2-}$161618$\checkmark$
Award one mark per row.
$\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
In a neutral atom the number of protons (or atomic number) is equal to the number of electrons.  In an ion, the number of protons is fixed by the element but the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons minus the charge.  The mass number is equal to the number of neutrons and protons.
The chemical symbol is written as $_{Z}^{A}\textrm{X}^{q}$ where $X$ is the chemical symbol, $A$ is the mass number, $Z$ is the atomic number, and $q$ is the charge.

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Fluorine isotopes are used in PET scans to detect cancer. A sample used in one scan contains two isotopes of fluorine: Fluorine isotopeMass (amu)% abundanceIsotope 118.0065%Isotope 2X35% The relative atomic mass of the fluorine in this sample is 18.35. - Determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in a neutral atom of isotope 1. [1] - State the relative mass and charge of each subatomic particle. [2] - Calculate the mass of isotope 2. [1] - Predict and explain one physical property that differs between the two isotopes. [2]
list.markScheme:
- protons 9, neutrons 9, AND electrons 9 $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The atomic number of fluorine is 9, so every fluorine atom has 9 protons. Isotope 1 has a mass number of 18, so it contains $18 - 9 = 9$ neutrons. In a neutral atom, the number of electrons is equal to the number of protons, so it has 9 electrons.
- charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0 AND electron = $-1\ \checkmark$
  masses: proton = 1, neutron = 1 AND electron $\sim 0$ / negligible $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The SI units for the masses and charges of the elementary particles are in the data booklet.
  Neutrons are uncharged.  Protons and electrons have charges $\pm 1.602177\times 10^{-19}text{ C}.$ Dividing by the fundamental unit of charge gives the typical charges: proton = +1, neutron = 0, and electron = $-1.$
  Neutrons and protons have similar masses: $m_n = 1.674927\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}$ and $m_p = 1.672622\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}$ while electrons are more than one thousand times smaller, $m_e = 9.109384\times 10^{-31}\text{ kg}.$ Dividing by the fundamental unit of mass, 1/12$^\text{th}$ the mass of a carbon$\text{--}$12 atom, $1.66054\times 10^{-27}\text{ kg},$ the masses in atomic mass units can be determined: proton = 1.0073, neutron = 1.0087, and electron = 0.0005.  In IB Chemistry, we typically use the simpler values proton = 1, neutron = 1, and electron $\sim 0$.
- $18.35 = (0.65)(18.00) + 0.35x\ ;\quad x = 19.00$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the isotopic masses.
  $A_r = \dfrac{65 \times 18.00 + 35 \times x}{100} = 18.35$$x = 19.00$
- any one of the following physical properties:
  
  - isotope 2 has a slower diffusion rate $\checkmark$
  - isotope 2 has a higher density $\checkmark$
  - isotope 2 has a (slightly) higher boiling/melting point $\checkmark$
  - isotope 2 has a higher mass $\checkmark$

  Allow the opposite about isotope 1.
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  Even though both isotopes of fluorine behave the same chemically, physical properties can vary due to their different masses. Isotope 2 has one extra neutron, making it slightly heavier.
  This would lead to a slower diffusion rate (heavier atoms move more slowly), higher density, and a slightly higher boiling or melting point.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an unknown element, according to its mass spectrum given below?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ee5ac3d6-1adf-4485-af22-64aafeda4c8c/images/7d116e30-4735-4b2b-b53c-803201dfd930/CH2010.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 1 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3}{100}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{10}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 1 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3}{10}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{100}$
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The student must determine the relative atomic mass of an element using its isotopic composition, as provided by a mass spectrum.
A mass spectrum provides information about each isotope of an element. Every peak corresponds to a specific isotope. The mass$\text{--}$to$\text{--}$charge ratio, $m/z,$ represents the atomic mass of the isotope since each ion is assumed to have a charge of $+1.$ The height of the peak, or relative intensity, is proportional to its abundance. The relative atomic mass, $A_r,$ can be calculated as the weighted average of the atomic mass of each isotope:
$A_r = \dfrac{m_1\times I_1 + m_2\times I_2 + \ldots}{I_1 + I_2 + \ldots}$
where $m$ is the mass of an isotope and $I$ is the intensity of its peak.
For this question,
$A_r = \dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{0.75 + 6 + 3.25}$$A_r = \dfrac{6\times 0.75 + 7\times 6 + 8\times 3.25}{10}$
This question is categorized as easy as the student must be able to calculate the relative atomic mass from a mass spectrum.

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Which isotope has the greatest number of neutrons?


- A. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^14_6C}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^16_8O}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^18_9F}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}\ce{^20_10Ne}$
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The number of neutrons in an atom can be found using the following formula:
Mass number = # protons + # neutrons
In the isotopes written in this question, the top number is the mass number and the lower number is the atomic number which equals the number of protons. Therefore, the number of neutrons for each is:
IsotopeMass NumberAtomic NumberProtonsNeutrons$\ce{^14_6C}$1466$14-6=8$$\ce{^16_8O}$1688$16-8=8$$\ce{^18_9F}$1899$18-9=9$$\ce{^20_10Ne}$201010$\mathbf{20-10=10}$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass given by the mass spectrum below?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0d0e9fca-9872-4cd3-86f9-1153ea9ebc23/images/e4e822e1-a79d-466e-9dcd-3fd96b14c975/CH1182v2.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$24.7
- B.$\hspace{1em}$27.4
- C.$\hspace{1em}$25.3
- D.$\hspace{1em}$22.3
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
An interpretation of the mass spectra is needed to determine the relative atomic mass from the isotopic composition. As intensities are given, these are proportional to the relative abundances of the isotopes in the sample. The calculation is shown below.
$A_r = \dfrac{(1 \times 22) + (2 \times 23) + (5 \times 25) + (1 \times 26) + (1 \times 28)}{1 + 2 + 5 + 1 + 1}$$A_r = \dfrac{247}{10} = 24.7$
This question is categorized as moderate, as students must be able to calculate the relative atomic mass from  isotopic abundances read from a mass spectrum.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Which of the following statements about atomic structure is incorrect?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The atomic nucleus contains over $99.9\%$ of an atom's mass.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$The number of neutrons in an atom typically increases as the atomic number increases.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$The mass of an electron is approximately $1/1836$ of a proton's mass.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Electrons orbit the nucleus in fixed orbits, similar to planets orbiting the Sun.
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
While early models of the atom, such as Bohr's atomic model, proposed that electrons move in fixed circular orbits around the nucleus, modern quantum mechanics has replaced this idea. Instead of fixed paths, electrons exist in probability clouds called orbitals, where their exact location cannot be determined. These orbitals are described by quantum mechanics, where electrons behave more like waves than particles in fixed orbits. Therefore, the idea of electrons orbiting the nucleus like planets is an outdated model that does not accurately describe atomic structure.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
The mass spectrum of an element shows only two peaks: one at $m/z = 50$ with relative abundance 2 and the other at $m/z = 52$ with relative abundance 1. What is the relative atomic mass of the element?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$51.00
- B. $\hspace{1em}$50.67
- C. $\hspace{1em}$50.50
- D. $\hspace{1em}$51.33
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
In a mass spectrum, the height of each peak reflects the relative abundance of that isotope.  The relative atomic mass can be determined from the weighted average of the isotopes:
$A_r = \dfrac{(2)(50) + (1)(52)}{3} = 50.67$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Which of the following correctly describes the forces that hold an atom together?


- A.$\hspace{1.em}$Electrostatic attraction holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while the strong nuclear force keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.
- B.$\hspace{1.em}$The strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.
- C.$\hspace{1.em}$Gravitational forces play a significant role in keeping electrons in orbit around the nucleus, along with electrostatic attraction.
- D.$\hspace{1.em}$The strong nuclear force is responsible for holding the entire atom together, including the electrons.
list.markScheme:
B

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The correct explanation is that the strong nuclear force holds protons and neutrons together in the nucleus, while electrostatic attraction keeps electrons bound to the nucleus.
The strong nuclear force is one of the four fundamental forces of nature and is responsible for overcoming the repulsion between positively charged protons, keeping them bound together with neutrons inside the nucleus. Without this force, the protons would repel each other due to their positive charges. On the other hand, electrostatic attraction is responsible for keeping negatively charged electrons bound to the positively charged nucleus. This force is much weaker than the strong nuclear force but is crucial for maintaining atomic structure. Contrary to one of the incorrect options, gravitational forces are negligible at the atomic scale, and the strong nuclear force does not play a role in keeping electrons attached to the nucleus.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: [Maximum marks: 6] Lead white is a pigment historically used by artists to achieve a warm white. It is no longer commonly used today due to its toxicity. - A sample from one painting was analyzed, and it was found that the lead pigment contained two isotopes of lead with mass numbers 206 and 208, in a ratio of $3:2.$ - Define the term isotope. [1] - Calculate the relative atomic mass of lead in the sample. Show your working [2] - In another pigment sample, the relative atomic mass of lead was determined to be 207.6. - Suggest why the relative atomic masses differ between the samples. [1] - Predict and explain whether the lead present in both samples would have the same physical and chemical properties. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - two atoms with the same number of protons and  different number of neutrons$\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    Isotopes are atoms of the same element (so they have the same number of protons), but they have different numbers of neutrons, which means they have different mass numbers. This affects the atomic mass but not the chemical behavior.
  - $\dfrac{(206.0)(3) + (208.0)(2)}{5}$ OR $\dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100}\ \checkmark$
    $206.8\ \checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    The relative atomic mass is the weighted average of the mass of each isotope. With a $3:2$ ratio, the percent abundance is $60:40.$
    $A_r = \sum \dfrac{\text{mass of isotope}\times \text{percent abundance}}{100}$$A_r = \dfrac{(206.0)(60) + (208.0)(40)}{100} = 206.8$

- 
  - any of the following:
    
    - different sources/geological origins of the lead $\checkmark$
    - different manufacturing/refining processes used to prepare pigments$\checkmark$
    - small sample size so different distribution of isotopes $\checkmark$

    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    Different lead samples can come from different mines or regions, and the natural abundance of isotopes varies slightly depending on the geological source. That is why one sample could have more $^{206}\ce{Pb},$ while another has more $^{208}\ce{Pb}.$
  - chemical properties same: same number of electrons/same electron configuration $\checkmark$
    physical properties may differ: different mass/boiling point/density/rate of diffusion $\checkmark$
    $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
    The chemical properties would be the same because both isotopes of lead have the same number of electrons. Chemical reactions depend on the electron arrangement, not the number of neutrons. However, the physical properties (like mass, density, diffusion rate, boiling/melting points) would be different due to the difference in mass.

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
Which of the following mass spectra corresponds to chlorine?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$B.$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/d3b68f53-bcaa-41cb-85ae-807f4feca98d/CH2117a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/fad74a6e-a33e-4fa7-8ab3-155d219cc9f7/CH2117b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/015d691d-93ee-47ee-92dd-688e431e6582/CH2117c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/97125542-1765-4f85-adab-fc5cc91bd2b1/images/51050137-8d3a-498d-bc05-d7bb55253a60/CH2117d.png)
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The relative atomic mass of chlorine is listed as 35.45 on the periodic table. This value is a weighted average of the masses of chlorine's naturally occurring isotopes, based on their relative abundances. Since 35.45 is much closer to 35 than to 37, it suggests that the lighter isotope $\ce{(^{35}Cl)}$ is more abundant than the heavier one $\ce{(^{37}Cl)}.$ In fact, chlorine exists as approximately 75% $\ce{(^{35}Cl)}$ and 25% $\ce{(^{37}Cl)}.$ Therefore, the correct mass spectrum must show two peaks at $m/z = 35$ and 37, with the peak at 35 being roughly three times taller than the one at 37, matching the natural isotope distribution that results in a relative atomic mass of 35.45.

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following mass spectrum?
$\hspace{10 em}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa9f46fc-be9a-4cfb-8873-f55b15040883/images/7324d25e-6103-4a9d-aa38-ffed61ee9688/CH1507.png)

$\hspace{10em}$


- A. $\hspace{1em}$150.50
- B. $\hspace{1em}$151.96
- C. $\hspace{1em}$152.00
- D. $\hspace{1em}$152.04
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
To calculate the relative atomic mass of an element with two isotopes, we need to first read the relative abundance from the graph. The abundance of the isotope with mass 151 is 48%  and the isotope with mass 153 has an abundance of  52%. A 50:50 mix would yield an average mass of 152, since the 153 abundance is slightly higher, we expect the answer to be just more than 152.  Only one answer makes sense, 152.04.
To quantitatively solve for the relative average mass $(A_r),$ we will estimate the relative abundances and take the weighted average of the masses of the two isotopes.
$A_r =\dfrac{(151)(48) + (153)(52)}{100} = 152.04$
To solve without a calculator, rewrite 153 as $151 + 2$ in the equation above to find
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151+2)(52)}{100}$
Distributing yields
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(48) + (151)(52) + (2)(52)}{100}$
Combine the first and second terms to find $(151)(48+52)$ or $(151)(100),$ so
$A_r = \dfrac{(151)(100) + (2)(52)}{100}$$A_r = 151 + \left(\dfrac{(2)(52)}{100}\right) = 151 + 1.04 = 152.04$

list.title: Question 28
list.content: Lithium is a low-density alkali metal that reacts vigorously with water. - Given the below data and referring to the periodic table, calculate the relative abundances of the isotopes of lithium. [3] IsotopeAtomic Mass$^{6}\textrm{Li}$6.015$^{7}\textrm{Li}$7.016 - State the definition of an isotope. [1] - Outline the concept of relative abundance. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Let x be the relative abundance of Lithium-7 and (100-x) be the relative abundance of lithium-6.
  Periodic table shows relative atomic mass of Lithium is 6.94. $\checkmark$
  Therefore,
  $\begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{7.016x + 6.015(100-x)}{100} &= 6.94 \\
  \dfrac{7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x}{100} &= 6.94 \\
  7.016x + 601.5 - 6.015x &= 694 \\
  1.001x + 601.5 &= 694 \\
  x &= 92.4 %
  \end{aligned}$
  The relative abundances of each isotope are 7.6 %$\checkmark$ for Li-6 and 92.4 % $\checkmark$  for Li-7.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  100 - 92.4 = 7.6
- Isotopes are atoms of an element with the same number of protons but with different number of neutrons. $\checkmark$
  $\textit{Award full mark if same number of protons AND different number of neutrons mentioned}$
- Relative abundance is the percent abundance in nature of a particular isotope. $\checkmark$

list.title: Question 29
list.content: Element Y has 4 stable isotopes. The table below shows the relative abundance and atomic masses of these isotopes. IsotopePercent abundanceAtomic mass11.40%203.97224.10%205.97322.10%206.98452.40%207.98 $\mbox{}\\[-25pts]$ - Calculate the relative atomic mass of the element. [2] - Identify the element. [1] - The atom of the element can form an ion with a charge of 4+. Determine the number of electrons in the ion. [1] - Determine the nuclear symbol of another corresponding ion of element Y given the numbers of subatomic particles: electrons = 80; neutrons = 122. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $A_r = (203.97) (0.014) + (205.97) (0.241)+ (206.98) (0.221) + (207.98)(0.524) \: \checkmark$
$A_r = 207.2 \: \checkmark$ 
$\textit{Award 2 marks for complete correct answer}$.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
Relative atomic mass is the sum of each atomic mass of each isotope multiplied by its percentage abundance.
- Pb \ lead $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element with a relative atomic mass equal to 207.2 is lead.
- 78 $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
The element is lead (Pb). Lead has an atomic number of 82. This means that a neutral atom of lead has 82 protons and 82 electrons. Its atom loses 4 electrons $(82-4)$ and becomes a cation with a charge of $4+$, $\ce{Pb^{4+}}.$
- Nuclear symbol: $\ce{^{204}_{82}Pb^{2+}}$ $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
There are 80 electrons in the corresponding ion. This means that the atom has lost 2 electrons and has a become an ion of charge 2+.
  Mass number = protons + neutrons = $82 + 122 = 204$

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
An element X has a relative atomic mass of 21.25.
Which mass spectrum corresponds to the isotopic composition of X?


- A.B.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/b0f297d5-de02-4d19-9f8e-aba47a085fa2/CH1249a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/85cc2686-44c7-4fc4-829e-caa5bf3d8634/CH1249b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/65ba8959-0722-4060-81f2-d7e431903fb7/CH1249c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/613ccf44-3f59-4a76-8d16-ca02f4c3e962/images/1cf0441e-3b60-41ab-8de6-0e574e270db3/CH1249d.png)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The relative atomic mass of an element is calculated as the weighted mean of the isotope masses, using their percentage abundances. For spectrum A, the calculation is:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (21 \times 25) + (22 \times 50)}{100} =  21.25$
This matches the value given in the question.
For comparison:
Spectrum B:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 10) + (21 \times 10) + (22 \times 80)}{100} =  21.70$
Spectrum C:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 90) + (21 \times 5) + (22 \times 5)}{100} =  20.15$
Spectrum D:
$A_r = \dfrac{(20 \times 25) + (22 \times 75)}{100} =  21.50$
This question is of medium difficulty because it tests the ability to apply the weighted mean formula systematically and also to reason qualitatively about how the distribution of isotopes shifts the average mass.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
Given below is the mass spectrum of the stable isotopes of rubidium (Rb). What is the relative atomic mass of rubidium?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e3db916-1d81-4664-9ab6-a5028574d644/images/627f7e43-e21d-4f9a-830f-cb78841ea511/CH0053.png)




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 85.5
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 86.7
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 85.9
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 87.4
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The approximate height of each peak is the relative abundance of each isotope.
$\hspace{4em}$Rb$\text{--}$85 $\sim$ 75 %
$\hspace{4em}$Rb$\text{--}$87 $\sim$ 25 %
Rb$\text{--}$85 is the most abundant isotope within a large difference, therefore,  the relative atomic mass should be closer to 85 than 87. 85.5 is the most reasonable answer.
Mathematically, we can calculate the weighted average of the mass:
$\begin{aligned} m &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 87\\
\\
 &= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times (85+2)\\
 \\
&= \dfrac{75}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 85 + \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2\\
\\
&   = 85 +  \dfrac{25}{100}\times 2 = 85.5\\
\end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass, $A_r$, of an unknown element found in a meteorite with the isotopic abundances shown below?
Isotope% Abundance$^{39}\ce{X}$80.0$^{40}\ce{X}$1.0$^{41}\ce{X}$19.0


- A.$\hspace{1em}$39.00
- B.$\hspace{1em}$40.00
- C.$\hspace{1em}$39.39
- D.$\hspace{1em}$40.50
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Based on calculations, the relative atomic mass of $\ce{X}$ is:
$A_r = \dfrac{\left(39\times 80.0\right)+\left(40\times 1.00\right)+(41\times 19.00\ )}{100} = 39.39$
Students are not required to work out the calculation. the $A_r$ cab be estimated to be close to 39 due to the high percent abundance of that isotope, but slightly higher due to the existence of the more massive isotopes.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following isotopic mass data?
$\newline \ $
Isotope mass% abundance15022.0015151.0015227.00


- A.$\hspace{1em}$151.00
- B.$\hspace{1em}$154.50
- C.$\hspace{1em}$1.51
- D.$\hspace{1em}$151.05
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
To answer this question, the student must use the following formula to find the relative atomic mass, $A_r$:
$A_r = \dfrac{m_1\times a_1 + m_2\times a_2 + \ldots}{100}$
where $m_i$ is the mass of an isotope in amu and $a_i$ is the abundance of that isotope expressed in percent.
For this question,
$A_r = \dfrac{(150 \times 22.00) + (151 \times 51.00) + (152 \times 27.00)}{100} = 151.05$
This question is categorized as medium difficulty because the student must know how to calculate a weighted average as opposed to a regular average. For example, if the student were to simply average 150, 151 and 152, then they would arrive at the answer 151.00 amu, while the true answer of 151.05 amu accounts for the weighted average of the isotopes.

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Element Y has a greater atomic number than element X whilst X has a greater relative atomic mass, $A_r,$  than element Y. What is the most likely explanation?


- A.$\hspace{1.em}A_r$ is determined by the number of protons and neutrons and increases with increasing atomic number.
- B.$\hspace{1.em}A_r$  is determined by the number of isotopes of an element and increases with increasing isotopes per element.
- C.$\hspace{1.em}A_r$ is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes.
- D.$\hspace{1.em}A_r$ is determined by its most abundant isotope.
list.markScheme:
C

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
The relative atomic mass of an element is determined by the mass and abundance of its isotopes. Even though element Y has a higher atomic number, element X has a greater relative atomic mass because its isotopes are heavier on average.
Real examples can be found with argon and potassium or cobalt and nickel.
$18$ $\\$ $\LARGE{\textrm{Ar}}$ $\\$ $\ \ \ \ \ 39.95\ \ \ \ \ $$19$ $\\$ $\LARGE{\textrm{K}}$ $\\$ $\ \ \ \ \ 39.10 \ \ \ \ \ $$\ \ \ \ \ $$27$ $\\$ $\LARGE{\textrm{Co}}$ $\\$ $\ \ \ \ \ 58.93\ \ \ \ \ $$28$ $\\$ $\LARGE{\textrm{Ni}}$ $\\$ $\ \ \ \ \ 58.69\ \ \ \ \ $
$\\$
elementatomic number /$\\$ number of protonsmost common isotopenumber of neutronsargon18argon$-40$22potassium19potassium$-39$20cobalt27cobalt$-59$32nickel28nickel$-58$30
Despite having a lower atomic number, argon has a greater relative atomic mass than potassium because its most abundant isotope is argon$-40,$ with 22 neutrons while potassium has lighter isotopes like potassium$-39$ with only 20 neutrons.  Similarly, cobalt has more neutrons than nickel so its relative atomic mass is higher than nickel's. This relative atomic mass depends more on isotopic composition than atomic number.

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Which mass spectrum corresponds to an element with a relative atomic mass of 24.3?


- A.B.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/b16ca96d-7658-4386-9f81-6682a6695a61/CH0680a.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/0ca0875d-a876-43ba-8c1c-5da6d9ac42f9/CH0680b.png)

C.D.$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/57ff099c-2118-4697-8801-60c751667d10/CH0680c.png)

$\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/e548e1d5-526e-4014-861a-57853525594b/CH0680d.png)
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
We are seeking the mass spectrum where the weighted average of the isotopes adds up to the atomic mass of magnesium, $A_r$. Using the markings on the $y-$axis, we can find the relative abundance of each isotope on a scale of 0 to 100. Given the molar mass of 24.3 in the question, we can assume the charges on the ions in the mass spectrum are +1 and thus the $m/z$ values on the $x-$axis are the isotopic masses.
$A_r = \dfrac{\textrm{mass}_1 \times \textrm{abundance}_1 + \textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{abundance}_2 + \ldots}{100} $
$\ $
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/b16ca96d-7658-4386-9f81-6682a6695a61/CH0680a.png)

 $\newline$ $A_r= \dfrac{24 \times 80 + 25 \times  10 + 26 \times  10}{100} = \answer{24.3}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/0ca0875d-a876-43ba-8c1c-5da6d9ac42f9/CH0680b.png)

 $\newline$ $A_r = \dfrac{24 \times 50 + 25 \times  30 + 26 \times  20}{100} = 24.7 $![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/57ff099c-2118-4697-8801-60c751667d10/CH0680c.png)

 $\newline$ $A_r = \dfrac{24 \times 90 + 26 \times  10}{100} = 24.2$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3cb0cb2c-5131-41e2-9fbc-fcbffc13e5eb/images/e548e1d5-526e-4014-861a-57853525594b/CH0680d.png)

 $\newline$  $A_r = \dfrac{24 \times 60 + 25 \times  40}{100} = 24.4$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
Different isotopes of titanium are listed below, with their corresponding abundances found in a sample:
$\ce{^{46}Ti}$$\ce{^{47}Ti}$$\ce{^{48}Ti}$$\ce{^{49}Ti}$$\ce{^{50}Ti}$% Abundance8.257.443.725.4175.18
Which statement is correct for this sample?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$The calculated relative atomic mass is 47.87; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium is consistent with samples found on Earth.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$The calculated relative atomic mass is 49.32; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$The calculated relative atomic mass is 48.00; the titanium may have an extraterrestrial origin.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The relative atomic mass from the isotopic abundance provided, is a weighted average of the isotope masses:
$A_r = \dfrac{46\times 8.25 + 47\times 7.44 + 48\times 3.72 + 49\times 5.41 + 50\times 75.18}{100}$$A_r = \dfrac{4931.83}{100} = 49.32$
The relative atomic mass listed for titanium in the periodic tableis 47.87 which differs from this sample with relative atomic mass 49.32. Isotopic abundances differ from one planet to another. The periodic table values are tabulated, considering the isotopic abundances on Earth. As a result, we can suggest that the sample of titanium tested may not belong to Earth.
This question is categorized as medium as students must calculate the relative atomic mass from data and understand the nature of tabulated values in the periodic table.

list.title: Question 37
list.content: The mass spectrum of chlorine gas is shown below: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bc5f423-1a7e-49fa-88a1-ba5cabcfaf57/images/f234c729-989b-4c86-af0f-564b5a022c77/CH0949.png) - Calculate the relative molecular mass of chlorine gas using the mass spectrum. [2] - State the identity of the particle responsible for the peak at 35 $m/z$. [1] - Calculate the relative atomic mass of chlorine using the mass spectrum. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $M_r = \dfrac{(70 \times 100) + (72 \times 65) + (74 \times 10)}{100 + 65 + 10} \: \checkmark$
$M_r = 70.97 \: \checkmark$
Award [2] for the correct answer.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Since chlorine gas exists as a diatomic molecule, the student needs to focus only on the masses for $\ce{Cl2}$ (as opposed to the Cl atom).
  This means that the masses at 35 $m/z$ and 37 $m/z$ can be ignored. The masses at 70 $m/z$, 72 $m/z$, and 74 $m/z$ are for chlorine gas composed of the combinations of isotopes for chlorine:
  $m/z = 70  \Longrightarrow \ce{^{35}Cl-^{35}Cl}$ 
$m/z = 72 \Longrightarrow \ce{^{35}Cl-^{37}Cl}$
$m/z = 74 \Longrightarrow \ce{^{37}Cl-^{37}Cl}$
  The answer is calculated as follows:
  $\begin{aligned}
  M_r &= \dfrac{(\textrm{mass}_ 1 \times \textrm{intensity}_1) + (\textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{intensity}_2) + \ldots}{\textrm{total intensity}} \\	
  &= \dfrac{(70 \times 100) + (72 \times 65) + (74 \times 10)}{100 + 65 + 10} = \answer{70.97}
  \end{aligned}$
- $\ce{^{35}Cl^+}\,\checkmark$
Do not award M1 if the + sign is missing.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
The detector for a mass spectrum will record cations that are either atoms, molecules, or fragments of molecules. In this case, the sample is of chlorine and so the peak at 35 $m/z$ is from a single atom of $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ that has been bombarded with electrons in the mass spectrometer, resulting in the charged particle, $\ce{^{35}Cl+}$.
- $A_r =\dfrac{(35 \times 83) + (37 \times 27)}{83 + 27} \: \checkmark$
$A_r = 35.49 \: \checkmark$
Award [2] for the correct answer
  $\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}$
Since the question is asking only for the relative atomic mass of a chlorine atom, the student needs to focus only on the masses for the isotopes of Cl (as opposed to $\ce{Cl2}$).
  This means that the masses at 70 m/z, 72 m/z, and 74 m/z can be ignored. The masses at 35 m/z and 37 m/z are for isotopes of chlorine and their abundance is used to calculate the relative atomic mass of chlorine.
  The answer is calculated as follows:
  $\begin{aligned}
  A_r &=\dfrac{(\textrm{mass}_1 \times \textrm{intensity}_1) + (\textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{intensity}_2) + …}{\textrm{total intensity}} \\
  &= \dfrac{(35 \times 83) + (37 \times 27)}{83 + 27} = \answer{35.49}
  \end{aligned}$

list.title: Question 38
list.content: Nickel has five stable isotopes. The masses and percent abundances are tabulated below: IsotopePercent abundance$^{58}$Ni68.08%$^{60}$Ni26.22%$^{61}$Ni1.14%$^{62}$NiA$^{64}$NiB - The relative atomic mass of nickel is 58.745, calculate the percent abundance of nickel$\text{--}$62 and nickel$\text{--}$64. [3] - State the number of protons and neutrons in nickel$\text{--}$62. [1] - Using your results from part (a), sketch the mass spectrum of nickel. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $58(68.08)+ 60(26.22) + 61(1.14)+ 62A+ 64B = 58.745(100)\ \checkmark$
  $A + B = 100 - (68.08 + 26.22 + 1.14) = 4.56\ \checkmark$
  $A = 4.36$ AND $B = 0.19\ \checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation:}}$
  The weighted average of the isotopes must be equal to the relative atomic mass of nickel, 58.74.
  $58.745 = \dfrac{(58)(68.08) + (60)(26.22) + (61)(1.14) + 62A + 64B}{100}$
  and the sum of the percent abundances must be 100.
  $68.08 + 26.22 + 1.14 + A + B = 100$
  Solving these two equations and two unknowns will give $A$ and $B.$ From equation 2,
  $A + B = 4.56\quad$ or $\quad B = 4.56 - A$
  Plugging that in to equation 1,
  $5874.5 = 5591.38 + 62A + 64(4.56 - A)$
  Solving for $A$ and $B$ give:
  $A = 4.36$ and $B = 0.20$
- protons: 28 AND neutrons:
  $62 - 28 = 34\ \checkmark$
- $\mbox{}\\[-30pts]$
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/601d52e5-637f-40a8-a317-f72d356818d1/images/e9bf53d1-b776-4c7f-9e98-4b9091d034a8/CH2113v2.png)


  Correct atomic masses for each isotope $\checkmark$
  Correct relative peak heights $\checkmark$
  Proper labeling of axes: $x\text{--}$axis: $m/z$ or atomic mass AND $y\text{--}$axis: relative abundance or intensity $\checkmark$
  $\textrm{\underline{Further Explanation:}}$
  A mass spectrum shows how many atoms of each isotope are present in a sample of an element, based on their mass$\text{--to--}$charge ratio $(m/z).$ Each line represents an isotope assuming a $+1$ charge. The height of the line corresponds to its abundance.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
What is the relative atomic mass of an element with the following mass spectrum?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/655b6395-7771-466f-97a8-4bdc04e9853b/images/3d245393-829c-4f47-9a58-0704b88d42e4/CH0948.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$77
- B. $\hspace{1em}$76.3
- C. $\hspace{1em}$76
- D. $\hspace{1em}$75.8
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The student must apply the following equation to answer this question:
$A_r = \dfrac{(\textrm{mass}_ 1 \times \textrm{abundance}_1) + (\textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{abundance}_2)+ \ldots}{100}$
Applying the values from the graph:
$A_r =\dfrac{(75 \times 20) + (76 \times 30) + (77 \times 50)}{100} = 76.3$
This question is of medium difficulty as the student only needs to extract data from the graph and apply it in a standard way.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
A sample of chlorine gas contains the isotopes $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{37}Cl}$. In the mass spectrum of a sample of chlorine gas, what is an interpretation of the peak at 74 $m/z$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- B. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- C. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of a chlorine molecule consisting of $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms
- D. $\hspace{1em}$It was caused by the detection of two $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The student must understand that in the mass spectrum of chlorine gas, there is more than one peak present and it consists of the combinations of molecules and atoms from the isotopes:


- $\ce{^{35}Cl^+}$ at 35 $m/z$
- $\ce{^{37}Cl^+}$ at 37 $m/z$
- $\ce{^{35}Cl_2^+}$ at 70 $m/z$ (composed of two $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms: 35 + 35 = 70)
- $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ $\ce{^{37}Cl^+}$ at 72 $m/z$ (composed of $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ and $\ce{^{35}Cl}$ atoms: 35 + 37 = 72)
- $\ce{^{37}Cl_2^+}$ at 74 $m/z$ (composed of two $\ce{^{37}Cl}$ atoms: 37 + 37 = 74)

This question is categorized as difficult because the student must interpret the mass spectrum data correctly based on the possible combinations from the chlorine isotopes.

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
Which property is most likely to differ between two isotopes of the same element?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$The strength of chemical bonds they form in compounds.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$Their ability to conduct electricity in the solid state.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$Their reactivity with acids and bases.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$Their diffusion rate in gases.
list.markScheme:
D

$\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}$
Isotopes have the same number of protons and electrons, meaning their chemical properties remain identical. This includes their ability to form chemical bonds and react with acids or bases. However, isotopes have different numbers of neutrons, leading to variations in their atomic mass which affects physical properties. In gases, the diffusion rate is inversely proportional to the square root of the atomic mass (as described by Graham's Law). Lighter isotopes diffuse faster than heavier isotopes, making diffusion rate the key property that differs between isotopes.
While some physical properties vary between isotopes, such as density and melting point, properties like electrical conductivity remain unchanged. Conductivity depends on the movement of free electrons, which is not influenced by the nuclear mass.

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
Element Z consists of two isotopes: $\ce{^{38}Z}$ and $\ce{^{39}Z}$. What is the approximate natural abundance of $\ce{^{38}Z}$?
$A_r(\ce{Z}) = 38.92$


- A.$\hspace{1em}$9.2%
- B.$\hspace{1em}$92%
- C.$\hspace{1em}$8%
- D.$\hspace{1em}$80%
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
The student must apply the following equation to answer this question:
$A_r =\dfrac{(\textrm{mass}_ 1 \times \textrm{abundance}_1) + (\textrm{mass}_2 \times \textrm{abundance}_2)+\ldots}{100}$
Since there are two isotopes for element Z and the total abundance is equal to 100%, then we can assume the following:
abundance of $\ce{^{38}Z} = x$abundance of $\ce{^{39}Z} = 100 - x$
Therefore, the answer can be calculated as follows:
$\begin{aligned}
38.92 &= \dfrac{38x + 39(100- x)}{100} \\
3892 &= 38x + 3900 - 39x \\
3892 - 3900 &= -x \\
x &= 8\%
\end{aligned}$
This question is categorized as difficult because the student must apply the formula to calculate the relative atomic mass in a mathematically challenging way.
